thread.title: Whaley's five touchdowns leads Jaguars past Ozen
thread.title_full: Whaley's five touchdowns leads Jaguars past Ozen

author: Dan Maher
title: Whaley's five touchdowns leads Jaguars past Ozen
text:
Close Image 1 of 8 Central's Devwah Whaley powers through Ozen's defense as he carries the ball into the enzone for the first Jaguar touchdown during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one another in what is a highlight of Beaumont high schools' legendary rivalry. Photo taken Friday, October 16, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Central's Devwah Whaley powers through Ozen's defense as he carries the ball into the enzone for the first Jaguar touchdown during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one another in what is a highlight of Beaumont high schools' legendary rivalry. Photo taken Friday, October 16, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Central's defense tries in vain to stop Ozen's Calvin Tyler as he sprints up the field during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one another in what is a highlight of Beaumont high schools' legendary rivalry. Photo taken Friday, October 16, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Central's John Ruffin undercuts Ozen's Josh Boyd as he runs the ball during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans ... more Photo: Kim Brent Image 5 of 8 Central's Vance Vallier brings down Ozen's Calvin Tyler during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one another in what is a highlight of Beaumont high schools' legendary rivalry. Photo taken Friday, October 16, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Central's Vance Vallier brings down Ozen's Calvin Tyler during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo ... more Photo: Kim Brent Image 6 of 8 Central's Delvin Bennet is tackled by Ozen's #30 during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one another in what is a highlight of Beaumont high schools' legendary rivalry. Photo taken Friday, October 16, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Central's Delvin Bennet is tackled by Ozen's #30 during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one ... more Photo: Kim Brent Image 7 of 8 Central's fans cheer as they continue their run against Ozen during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to outdo one another in what is a highlight of Beaumont high schools' legendary rivalry. Photo taken Friday, October 16, 2015 Kim Brent/The Enterprise Central's fans cheer as they continue their run against Ozen during the annual Soul Bowl Friday night at the Thomas Center. The rivalry extends well beyond the playing field, with bands and fans looking to ... more Photo: Kim Brent Whaley's five touchdowns leads Jaguars past Ozen 1 / 8 Back to Gallery 
Central used a rushing attack that generated six touchdowns and 248 yards to rebuff every comeback attempt Ozen threw at them, holding off the Panthers for a 43-27. 
WHAT HAPPENED 
Central's special teams and defense set its offense up with short fields throughout the game, blocking two punts and creating four Ozen turnovers. 
Standout Central running back Devwah Whaley was the prime beneficiary, scoring five short rushing touchdowns, while amassing 125 yards on 24 carries. Theo Foster also scored a short rushing touchdown and gained 103 yards on 13 carries to give the Jaguars another offensive spark. 
Central built a 22-0 lead before Ozen scored on its final possession of the first half and its opening possession of the second to trim the margin to 22-14. Foster's touchdown countered Ozen's early second half touchdown, and a later Panthers touchdown that pulled them back to within eight points was immediately answered by Whaley's fourth touchdown. 
"(Playing Ozen) is a lot of motivation," Whaley said. "We had a great week of practice to get ready. We worked hard all week and came in pretty confident." 
TURNING POINT 
Calvin Tyler, Jr. hauled in a 37–yard scoring strike from Josh Boyd to pull Ozen within 29-21 on the first play from scrimmage in the fourth quarter, but in Central's next series, Whaley and Foster ripped off their longest runs of the game on successive plays to propel Central into the red zone. 
Whaley's 3-yard touchdown run one play after Foster's run essentially gave Central control of the game. 
MOST SPECTACULAR PLAY 
Central kept focusing its offense around straight forward handoffs to Whaley and Foster that sent them into the heart of their offensive line. 
The results weren't dramatic, with Whaley's 37 yard run in the fourth quarter the only Jaguars rush of more than 20 yards, but yardage gained after contact by Whaley and Foster consistently kept Central's drives alive. 
"If you have a good week of practice, it's real easy to execute," Whaley said. "I've got to give it all up to my offensive line for creating holes." 
BY THE NUMBERS 
Tyler has been explosive all season, so his 84 yards and one rushing touchdown on 24 carries was well below average for him. 
Boyd threw for 266 yards and two touchdowns, but most of that was when Ozen was in desperate comeback mode. 
The numbers that stood out most, however, were four Panther turnovers compared to zero by the Jags. Ozen's only two punt attempts were both blocked by Central. 
"We didn't turn the ball over for the first time this year and that's big," Central coach Toby Foreman said. "I think the difference in the game, though, was special teams." 
RECORDS 
Central 3-4, 3-1. Ozen 3-4, 1-3. 
HE SAID IT 
"(Friday night) was one mistake after one mistake after another mistake after a mistake," Ozen coach David Suggs said. "Those are the things we did and we've got to take responsibility for them." 
NEXT UP 
Central plays at Vidor at 7 p.m., Friday. Ozen plays host to Port Neches–Groves at 7 p.m. Friday. Southeast Texas sports news
